mods.abstract: Sepia toned photograph, mounted on board, of a triumphal arch with people standing underneath it. The arch depicts portraits of Carlos Manuel de Céspedes (right) and Ignacio Agramonte (left) and includes a symbol of a key.

Ignacio Agramonte y Loynáz (1841-1873) and Carlos Manuel de Céspedes (1819-1974) were prominent figures in the Ten Years’ War (1868-1878), Cuba's first large-scale war for independence. Céspedes, a sugar planter known as the Padre de la Patria (Father of the Country), proclaimed independence from Spain and established the Republic of Cuba in October 1868. One year later, the new government enacted the first constitution abolishing slavery and annexing the country to the United States, Agramonte, an important military figure from the beginning of the rebellion and later an elected secretary to the provincial government, was integral to the creation of the constitution. Ultimately, the rebellion failed due to tensions among the rebel leaders and exhaustion of material resources necessary to fund the war. In 1878, the two sides signed the Pact of Zanjon officially ending the war.
